awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Abstract
Films and membranes are a critical area of chemical and materials research for applications including separations, catalysis, and energy technologies.  The development of new films and membranes that possess next-generation properties will be enabling for many of these applications.  With support from the Solid State and Materials Chemistry program in the Division of Materials Research, this project will produce a general method for preparing new membrane materials that contain small particles of a highly porous solid imbedded within the membrane.  These membranes will exhibit new and interesting properties that cannot be achieved with existing materials.  We will also use these membranes to demonstrate proof-of-concept studies for their use in removal of toxic molecules from water.  In addition, this proposal includes support for the Science Policy Internship Program, which supports STEM (science, technology, engineering, math) students at the University of California Center in Washington D.C.  The program includes activities such as coursework, seminars, tours, and science policy internships.  This distinctive program engages primarily underrepresented and women students, across the University of California system, toward the goal of creating a generation of scientists that better understand and value their role in society and government.

Technical Abstract
This research program will develop hybrid membranes prepared from both hard metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) and soft organic polymers (termed MOF/polymer composite membranes or MPCMs).  A general, versatile, and scalable method has been developed for preparing supported and free-standing MPCMs.  Drop casting combined with 'doctor-blading' methods will be used to create supported and free-standing MPCMs.  This program will develop MPCMs that:  a) can be readily prepared and scaled; b) employ a wide range of MOF materials; and c) can operate as membranes for chemical separations.  This proposal will greatly advance the use of MOFs by establishing a general approach for casting uniform, hybrid films that can be delaminated into robust membranes that can be manipulated, integrated into devices or systems, such that the physical properties of MOFs can be exploited in otherwise inaccessible applications. The utility of these materials will be demonstrated in separations and water purification.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
In this research project entitled, ?Integrated, Functional MOF@Polymer Membranes? our laboratory produced advanced materials for a range of commercial, technological, and industrial applications.  In addition to these technological advances, approximately a half-dozen students received top-notch scientific training, producing 10 scientific publications in highly regarded research journals (with acknowledged support from this award).  Finally, through the broader impacts efforts of this program five undergraduate students were awarded fellowships through the Science Policy Internship Program, which enabled them to spend a summer in Washington D.C. performing internships that bridged between science and public policy.

Porous solids are materials that have very low densities and as such possess very large internal surface areas.  One class of porous solids are Metal-Organic Frameworks, referred to at MOFs.  MOFs can be envisaged as molecular ?jungle gyms?, comprised of struts (the ?organic? component) connected at nodes (the ?metal? component).  Like a playground?s jungle gym, MOFs are rigid structures that have large, open interior spaces.  This results in massive surface areas; indeed, one gram of a typical MOF (less than the mass and volume of a sugar cube) can possess a surface area greater than that of football field.  The combination of a huge surface area in a small mass/volume endows MOFs with very unique properties that hold tremendous potential for applications in gas storage, chemical separations, and drug delivery.  For example, the gas uptake properties of MOFs have been examined for use in carbon dioxide capture from power generation and for onboard hydrogen storage for hydrogen-powered fuel cell automobiles.

Despite their tremendous potential commercial and industrial uses, the commercialization of MOFs has been limited because they are formed as microcrystalline or crystalline solids.  The appearance of MOFs somewhere in between baby powder and table salt.  This powder or crystal solid form limits the ability these materials to be integrated and utilized into different technologies.  Therefore, this research program sought to combine MOFs with polymers (i.e., plastics) to get stretchable, malleable materials that still possessed the underlying properties of the MOF.  The ultimate goal was to produce composite materials that retain the desired properties of both the MOF (e.g., high surface area) with that of the polymer (e.g., easy processibility into fibers, films, coatings, etc.).  By creating a composite material that has the unusual properties of MOFs, but otherwise look and behave like polymers, this program sought to advance the use of MOFs into more useful ?form factors? for technological applications.

This research program achieved its stated aims.  A number of MOF+polymer combinations and formulations were prepared and studied.  It was found that some MOF+polymer combinations gave flexible materials that retained the high surface areas of the MOFs, while other MOF+polymer composites did not.  Some MOF+polymer composites were brittle, not retaining the plasticity of the polymer.  Other MOF+polymer combinations were plastic and flexible, but no longer possessed the high surface areas typical of MOFs.  Sophisticated methods were used to investigate both successful and unsuccessful MOF+polymer composites to develop a roadmap to obtaining the best material combinations.  As proposed, the results of these studies have provided an initial set of tools and rules for designing useful MOF+polymer combined materials.

In addition to these scientific accomplishments, traniees from this program went on to successful positions in academia, industry, or government.  For example, former graduate student Dr. Jessica Moreton is now working for a company focused on developing MOFs in sensor devices (Matrix Sensors), while another former student, Dr. Joseph Palomba is now working for the Natick Soldier Center in Massachusetts.  A former postdoctoral trainee, Dr. Kyle Bentz is working for the large biotech company Illumina as a research scientist.

The broader impacts of this program included the Science Policy Internship Program (SPIP) in Washington D.C.  SPIP encourages undergraduate STEM students to learn about science policy.  SPIP awardees stay at the University of California center in Washington DC (UCDC, http://www.ucdc.edu) and perform internships in the field of science policy.  Students from several of the UC campuses have participated; the majority have been women and underrepresented students.  This unique program gives STEM students an unconventional, but critically important perspective on the interactions between government and scientists.  This awarded supported five SPIP fellows:

  • Rico Oguchi from UC Davis majoring in Global Disease Biology interned at the Consortium for Universities for Global Health (CUGH).
  • Bianca Gomez from UC Santa Barbara majoring in Chemistry internted at the Consortium for Universities for Global Health (CUGH).
  • June Hong from UC Davis majoring in Mathematics interned at the Dept. of Health and Human Services (Maryland).
  • Anass Malabeh from UC Irvine majoring in Mechanical Engineering and Physics interned at the Environmental Protection Agency, Office of Research and Development?s (ORD) Office of Science Policy (OSP).
  • Xiaotong Wang from UC Davis majoring in Statistics interned at the Government Research Relations for the Office of Research Affairs at UC San Diego.

 


Last Modified: 10/05/2021
Modified by: Emmanuel A Theodorakis
